Increased Cultural Understanding: If all countries adopted a single universal language, it would make it easier for people from different cultures to communicate and understand each other. This could lead to increased cultural understanding and empathy, as well as better collaboration between nations.

Reduced Language Barriers: A single universal language would eliminate the need for translation, which can be time-consuming and expensive. This could reduce language barriers in many areas, including business, education, and healthcare.

Improved Global Connectivity: With a common language, people from different parts of the world would be able to connect more easily and quickly. This could improve global connectivity and help to break down geographic barriers.

Potential for Standardization: A single universal language could also lead to the standardization of various industries and fields. For example, if everyone spoke the same language, it would be easier to develop and implement new technologies and systems.

Challenges for Native Speakers: However, adopting a single universal language could also pose challenges for native speakers. They may feel their culture and identity are being threatened by the dominance of a new language. Additionally, there may be resistance to adopting a new language, particularly among older generations who have grown up speaking their own language.
